journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Non-destructive inspection of carbon-fibre-reinforced polymers using lock-in thermography

article-meta.aff: 1School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, China
2Department of Automation Measurement and Control, Harbin Institute of Technology, China

author-notes.corresp: Zijun Wang, School of Aeronautics and Astronautics, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China, Chengdu, China. Email: wangzijun@uestc.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Development in composite materials technology has led to wide applications of such promising materials. The detection and characterisation of the wide range of defects requires a number of specialised non-destructive methods. In this article, lock-in thermography was used to identify defects in carbon-fibre-reinforced polymer specimens. The effects of modulation frequency and incident angle were discussed. The amplitude and the phase images were compared. A multi-objective evolutionary algorithm was used to optimise the experimental frequency, time and other parameters of infrared NDT. The temperature difference between the non-destructive and the defect regions was used as evaluation function. The results show this method can provide theoretical parameters for engineering inspection.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: One primary objective in aerospace industry is to reduce the weight of aircraft structures as much as possible, so carbon-fibre-reinforced polymers (CFRPs) and glass-fibre-reinforced polymers (GFRPs) have gained tremendous popularity.1 The defects are induced during the fabrication process will lead to reduced structural performance and safety. Therefore, detection of these defects is very important and all kinds of methods are used to defects detecting such as ultrasonic, thermal imaging, photomicroscopy, etc.2 The thermal imaging is a non-contact measurement method with fast and large-area detecting ability. In imaging methods, lock-in thermography methods have potential for maximising detectable defect depth compared with pulse heating methods. Many qualitative approaches were developed to investigate the effects on images of a number of defect-related parameters, such as type, depth, size and thickness.3 GFRP specimens were already tested and evaluated with lock-in thermography.2,4 The optimum parameters should be studied to obtain the best inspection result. In this article, lock-in thermography inspection of CFRP composites was investigated. The modulation frequency and the incident angle of the light source were discussed. Based on the experimental investigation, the factors affecting the detectivity of amplitude and phase images were discussed.

sec.title: Theory
sec.p: In Lock-in thermography, energy is delivered to the object’s surface as periodic thermal waves, so several experiences must be performed to cover the entire specimen thickness. The equation in a one-dimensional case has a sinusoidal solution consisting of an attenuation factor and a time-dependent wave along the z-axis5 (1)T(z,t)=T0exp(-ωρcz2λ)·cos(ω·t+ωρcz2λ) where λ is the thermal conductivity (W/(m·K)); ω the angular modulation frequency of the heat source (rad); ρ the density (kg/m3); c the heat capacity (J/(kg·K)); z the z-axis coordinate (mm); and thermal diffusion length μ is defined as (2)μ=λ2π=απf where α=k/ρc is diffusivity.

Images from each part are averaged to produce four images with averaged signals of thermal cameras S1, S2, S3 and S4. The phase φ and the amplitude A for each pixel are then calculated as (3)φ=arctanS1-S3S2-S4 (4)A=(S1-S3)2+(S2-S4)2 The phase reveals the required information about depth. The relationship for the depth of a defect z can be devised as6 (5)z∝φd·μ where φd is the phase of a defective region. The absolute phase contrast Δφ is calculated as (6)Δφ=φd-φsa where φsa is the phase of a non-defective sound region.

sec.title: Equipment
sec.p:
Surface temperature was monitored by an FPA infrared (IR) camera (3 to 5 µm), which takes a series of thermal images with 320 × 256 pixels, and works at sampling frequency of 37 Hz. Two high energy lamps were used as heating sources. An induction method was used to generate periodically modulated electric current by a two-channel signal generator. Sinusoidal waveform was used as the modulation signal, and its frequency was adjusted from 0.1 to 1.2 Hz according to the thermal conductivity and the thickness of the specimen. The number of total thermal images to be taken was determined by the heating period, the modulation frequency and the sampling frequency. The modulated AC signal was amplified by the high frequency amplifier. Continuous IR data from the specimen’s surface were measured by the IR camera (14 bits digital signal), and transferred to the lock-in processing electronics in the lock-in thermography system. The digital lock-in processing of the IR signal was carried out in the processing electronics using the frequency modulation signal from the signal generator (Figure 1).7 Figure 1.
Experimental setup of lock-in thermography system.
Figure 2.
Structure of CFRP skin honeycomb modelling defect specimen.
CFRP: carbon-fibre-reinforced polymer.

sec.title: Specimens
sec.p: Delamination is one common defect in CFRP structures. When delamination occurs, there is usually an air gap between two adjacent layers. To investigate the detectivity of lock-in thermography, a calibration specimen should be made which contains expected defects of various sizes and at various depths. We used a thin film as implanted defects in the CFRP delamination. The sizes of the square defects are 6, 8, 10, 15, 20 and 25 mm. Defects were inserted at the depths of 0.5, 1.0, and 1.5 mm under the surface. Figure 2 is a schematic of a specimen.

sec.title: Effect of modulation frequency
sec.p:
Modulation frequency is adjusted properly according to defect depth. From experience, lower frequency should be used to detect deeper defects, so the experimental parameters are presented in Table 1. Table 1.
Experimental parameters
Depths, Ld (mm) 0.5 1.0 1.5
Modulation frequency, fe (Hz) ≤0.42 ≤0.12 ≤0.047
Analytical periods 1∼3
Sampling frequency, fs (Hz) 37
Light source power (kW) 2
Distance between light source and specimen (m) 2∼3
Distance between IR camera and specimen (m) 2∼3
IR: infrared.

Figure 3 shows the amplitude images and the phase images of CFRP specimens. The defect depths are different. Amplitude differences and phase differences exist between the defective and the non-defective regions. In the amplitude images, the amplitude is variable depend on the defective depths. The deeper defects as 1.5 mm are more difficult for detection. The small defective regions (6 × 6 mm2) can hardly be seen at the depth over 1.0 mm, and the least distance between the defects can hardly be distinguished. When the depth is less than 1.0 mm, the smaller defect can be detected. The phase images have better resolution than the amplitude images. Figure 3.
Results of CFRP skin honeycomb specimens. (a) Amplitude images; (b) Phase images.
CFRP: carbon-fibre-reinforced polymer.

sec.title: Effect of incident angle
sec.p:
Thermographic analysis is based on estimating the reflectivity of temperature variation of the materials. The reflect light of specimen surface or other illuminants may affect the detection results. The incident angle θ is the angle between the light source and the specimen, which is adjusted to reduce the above effects. The principle of adjustment is shown in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Principle of incident angle adjustment.

In order to study the influence of incident angle on the test results, different incident angles were used. The signal to noise ratio (SNR) of the defect regions can be defined in equations (7) and (8). The influence of incident angle can be estimated by the phase SNR and the amplitude SNR. The reference points are shown in Figure 5. (7)SNRphase=μ(Ph)defect-μ(Ph)non-defectσ(Ph)non-defect (8)SNRAm=μ(Am)defect-μ(Am)non-defectσ(Am)non-defect where μ(Ph)defect and μ(Ph)non-defect refer to the phase values; μ(Am)defect and μ(Am)non-defect refer to the amplitude values; σ(Ph)non-defect and σ(Am)non-defect refer to the standard deviations of phase and amplitude, respectively; and the subscripts ‘defect’ and ‘non-defect’ refer to the defect and the non-defect regions, respectively. Figure 5.
Reference defect points, the region selected for calculation of SNR..
SNR: signal to noise ratio.

The depth of the defects chosen is Ld = 0.5 mm. The parameters are presented in Table 2. Table 2.
Experimental parameters
Modulation frequency, fe (Hz) 0.15
Analytical periods 2
Sampling frequency, fs (Hz) 37
Light source power (kW) 1
Light incident angle, θ (°) 0 45 60 90

The incident angles are 0°, 45°, 60° and 90°, and the other experimental parameters are the same. The results are shown in Figure 6. With the given conditions, the changing incident angle has greater influence on the amplitude images, because of the uneven heating on the specimen. As the incident angle increases, especially over 45°, the defects cannot be seen clearly from the amplitude images. However, the small defects can be seen in all phase images under any incident angle. It shows that the phase images are not sensitive to the uneven heating on the specimen surface. Figure 6.
Amplitude and phase images with different incident angles (0°, 45°, 60° and 90°). (a) amplitude images; (b) phase images.

Figure 7 shows the SNR in the defect regions. As the incident angle increases, the SNR of amplitude image decreases. At a given incident angle, a smaller defect has the lower SNR from an amplitude image. As the incident angle changes, the SNR of a phase image is better than that of an amplitude image. The SNR of phase images is more than 3 and even as high as 10, but the SNR of the amplitude images is less than 3. In conclusion, if the incident angle is less than 60° (θ < 60°), the lock-in thermography can produce satisfying results in the phase images. Figure 7.
SNR of local defect region for amplitude images and phase images.
SNR: signal to noise ratio.

sec.title: Multi-objective evolutionary algorithm
sec.p: The temperature on the specimen surface is related to specimen material, defect material and defect depth. The phase of the thermal wave is also related to them. So it must be an optimum frequency for an inspection under certain condition, such as given defect martial and defect depth. In practical inspection, the optimum frequency should be selected to get the best phase images. The study on the optimum excitation frequency which will give a maximum temperature for a given condition was conducted.8 A multi-objective evolutionary algorithm (MOEA) was used to optimise the experimental frequency, time and other parameters. The temperature difference and the phase difference between the non-destructive and the defect regions are used as evaluation functions, and the optimised parameters are achieved by MOEA. The goal of the algorithm is to maximise the differences, minimise the modulation frequency and get the frequency ω and the excitation time t (or the analytical period N).
The estimate functions 1–3 in Group 1 are as follows (9)f(1)=angle[Ts] (10)f(2)=I0e-Lc/μc·cos(ωt-Lc/μc)-I0cos(ωt) (11)f(3)=ω

The estimate function 1 produces the phase value of the thermal wave of the specimen surface. The estimate function 2 produces the temperature difference between the defect and the non-defect surfaces. The estimate function 3 produces the modulation frequency.
The estimate function in Group 2 is changed from function 1 in Group 1 as (12)f(1)=angle[Is]
where Is means the intensity of the thermal wave of the specimen surface. So function 1 produces the phase values of the thermal wave signal.

The parameters of the defects are presented in Table 3. Table 3.
Parameters of defects
Defect A Defect B Defect C Defect D
Depths, Lc (mm) 0.8 1.3 1.8 2.3
Thickness, Ld (mm) 4.2 3.7 3.2 2.7

MOEA is used with the following parameters: population = 200, generations = 500 and popsize = 50. The results of the estimate functions are presented in Table 4. Here, the better parameters are presented in Table 4. The goals of the algorithm are to obtain the maximum value of functions 1 and 2, and the minimum value of function 3. For different defect parameters, the optimum modulation frequency and modulation time are not the same. As in Table 4, the optimum modulation frequency is 0.1 to 0.3 Hz, and the optimum modulation time is no more than 10 s. The phase difference and the temperature difference are obvious when the optimum parameters are selected. Table 4.
Results of MOEA arithmetic
Modulation frequency, fe (Hz) Modulation time, t (s) Estimate function 1, ϕ (°) Estimate function 2, ΔT (°C) Estimate function 3, ω (rad)
Group1-A 0.1145 8.0160 −89.2624 −3.3683 0.7195
Group1-A 0.3763 2.3905 −87.8320 −5.9125 2.3642
Group2-A 0.2269 3.9659 −88.5926 −4.7069 1.4261
Group2-A 0.3629 2.4583 −87.8562 −5.8240 2.2806
Group1-B 0.1829 4.7919 −87.2384 −6.5568 1.1497
Group1-B 0.2346 3.8584 −86.4809 −7.3361 1.4739
Group2-B 0.1044 8.1414 −88.3304 −4.9891 0.6562
Group2-B 0.1764 5.1024 −87.2921 −6.4935 1.1081
Group1-C 0.1982 9.6597 −84.3560 −8.9494 1.2450
Group1-C 0.2319 8.2248 −83.4147 −9.5516 1.4575
Group2-C 0.1077 8.2704 −86.8534 −6.9504 0.6768
Group2-C 0.1917 4.6691 −84.5062 −8.8394 1.2048
Group1-D 0.0999 8.7075 −85.3359 −8.1254 0.6277
Group1-D 0.1353 6.7080 −83.7234 −9.3669 0.8499
Group2-D 0.2114 4.2686 −80.2934 −11.1122 1.3283
Group2-D 0.1728 5.2179 −82.0077 −10.3018 1.0857
MOEA: multi-objective evolutionary algorithm.

The phase images with different modulation frequencies are shown in Figure 8. The modulation frequency is around 0.1 Hz when the defects in the phase images can be seen clearly; above 0.3 Hz, the defects can hardly be seen. The results show the correspondence with the results of MOEA. Using the parameters that get from MOEA can get preferably experimental effects. Figure 8.
Phase images with different frequency. (a) 0.05 Hz; (b) 0.1 Hz; (c) 0.2 Hz; (d) 0.25 Hz; e) 0.325 Hz; (f) 0.6 Hz.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Lock-in thermography was used in the detection of the CFRPs. The phase images inspection was proven to be effective in detection of small defects. Different modulation frequencies were used for studying the detection ability of small defects. The lower modulation frequency was used for the deeper defect. The incident angles of the light source were also discussed. SNR of the images was defined as parameters to estimate the effects of the changing incident angles. The phase images are less sensitive than the amplitude images. The MOEA results can give the range of the experimental parameters, such as modulation frequency and modulation time.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was supported by the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities (nos. ZYGX2010J115 and ZYGX2011J129).
